problem_metadata.title: Sum of Even Numbers After Queries
problem_metadata.content:
You are given an integer array nums and an array queries where queries[i] = [vali, indexi].

For each query i, first, apply nums[indexi] = nums[indexi] + vali, then print the sum of the even values of nums.

Return an integer array answer where answer[i] is the answer to the ith query.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,2,3,4], queries = [[1,0],[-3,1],[-4,0],[2,3]]
Output: [8,6,2,4]
Explanation: At the beginning, the array is [1,2,3,4].
After adding 1 to nums[0], the array is [2,2,3,4], and the sum of even values is 2 + 2 + 4 = 8.
After adding -3 to nums[1], the array is [2,-1,3,4], and the sum of even values is 2 + 4 = 6.
After adding -4 to nums[0], the array is [-2,-1,3,4], and the sum of even values is -2 + 4 = 2.
After adding 2 to nums[3], the array is [-2,-1,3,6], and the sum of even values is -2 + 6 = 4.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [1], queries = [[4,0]]
Output: [0]

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 104
  • -104 <= nums[i] <= 104
  • 1 <= queries.length <= 104
  • -104 <= vali <= 104
  • 0 <= indexi < nums.length

submissions.code:
class Solution:
    def sumEvenAfterQueries(self, nums: List[int], queries: List[List[int]]) -> List[int]:
        # I overcomplicated things for this question argh.
        ansarray = [0]*len(nums)
        runningsum = sum(num if num % 2 == 0 else 0 for num in nums)
        for idx,(val,i) in enumerate(queries):
            prev = nums[i]

            if prev % 2 == 0: # We remove the element from the runningsum if its even
                runningsum -= prev
            
            nums[i] += val
            if nums[i] % 2 == 0:
                runningsum += nums[i]
            
            ansarray[idx] = runningsum
        return ansarray[:len(queries)]
